bioghist.p: The Free Library of Philadelphia was founded in 1891 as the city's first public library system. Its Rare Book Department, among the largest in American public libraries, exists to serve the people of Philadelphia, as well as the students, scholars, and researchers who use its collections. The Rare Book Department's holding span 5000 years, from cuneiform tablets to 20th century literary manuscripts. Among the many collecting areas of the department are incunabula, American, European, and Oriental manuscripts, art and artist's papers, children's books and manuscripts, manuscripts and correspondence of American and British authors, examples of calligraphy, and Pennsylvania German fraktur. The Rare Book Department has major collections of Oliver Goldsmith, Charles Dickens, Edgar Allan Poe, Horace editions, Beatrix Potter, Arthur Rackham, and Robert Lawson.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of historical documents written or signed by notable historical figures. The collection includes American, British, and European materials; the majority of the items are American. Among the American materials are the William McIntire Elkins collection of Jay Treaty Papers (1794). These include letters of George Washington, John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, James Madison, Timothy Pickering, Alexander Hamilton, James Monroe, Thomas Rodney, Henry Knox, Rufus King, Charles Cotesworth Pinckney, Thomas Pinckney, John Jay, and others. There are typed transcriptions of some of the letters in the collection. Other American historical documents and letters include items signed by: Neil Armstrong, Nicholas Biddle, John Wilkes Booth, C. W. Camac, Silas Deane, Albert Einstein, Ira Gershwin, Oliver Wendell Holmes, John Paul Jones, Tadeusz Kosciuszko, Marquis de Lafayette, Benjamin Franklin, Henry Lee, Joseph Leidy, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, Abbott Lawrence Lowell, Charles Mann, Gouverneur Morris, Robert Morris, William Penn, Benjamin Rush, William T. Sherman, Bushrod Washington, William White, and Oliver Wolcott. In addition to the Jay Treaty papers, other presidential letters included in this collection are signed by John Adams, John Quincy Adams, James Buchanan, Abraham Lincoln, William H. Taft, Herbert Hoover, Thomas Jefferson, and Rutherford B. Hayes. The most recent document in the collection is a thank you letter signed by Barbara Bush. In addition to the American materials, the collection includes British and European documents. These include letters of kings and queens of England (Anne, Charles I, Charles II, Edward VII, George II, George III, George IV, George V, James I, James II, Victoria, William III, and William IV); Oliver Cromwell; Horatio Nelson; Napoleon; vicomte de Chateaubriand; and Jenny Lind. The oldest document in the collection is a fourteenth century deed concerning a parish church in Shropshire.
